Questions: Hi there, I’m a physical therapist. What brings you in today?
Yes Type: Hi, I’ve been having some low back pain for a few days now and it’s really bothering me.

Questions: Hi there, my name is [insert name] and I’m a physical therapist. What brings you in today?
Yes Type: Hi, I’ve been having some low back pain for a few days now and it’s really bothering me.

Questions: I see. Can you tell me how the pain started?
Yes Type: Honestly, I’m not sure. It just kind of started hurting one day and has been getting worse.

Questions: Okay, can you describe the pain for me? Is it a dull ache or more sharp and stabbing?
Yes Type: It’s more of a dull ache, but it can get pretty intense at times.

Questions: Got it. And what seems to make the pain worse? Are there any specific activities that cause it to flare up?
Yes Type: Well, sitting for long periods of time definitely makes it worse, and bending over or lifting heavy objects makes it hurt too.

Questions: I see. And are there any activities or positions that help ease the pain?
Yes Type: Yeah, actually lying down on my back with a pillow under my knees seems to help a bit.

Questions: That’s good to know. How about the pain throughout the day? Does it tend to be worse at certain times or does it stay consistent?
Yes Type: It’s pretty consistent throughout the day, but it does tend to get worse towards the end of the day.

Questions: Okay, thanks for letting me know. Have you had any previous injuries to your back or any other medical issues that could be related?
Yes Type: No, not really. I’ve had some occasional back pain in the past, but nothing like this.

Questions: Alright, and are you currently taking any medications?
Yes Type: No, I’m not taking anything for it.

Questions: Alright, thanks for letting me know. Have you received any previous treatment for this pain?
Yes Type: No, I haven’t.

Questions: Okay. Lastly, I just need to ask you a few more questions related to any red or yellow flag symptoms. Have you experienced any numbness or tingling in your legs or feet?
Yes Type: No, I haven’t.

Questions: Okay, good to know. Have you had any loss of bladder or bowel control?
Yes Type: No, definitely not.

Questions: Okay, and have you experienced any recent unexplained weight loss or fever?
Yes Type: No, I haven’t.

Questions: Great, thank you for answering all of those questions. Based on what you’ve told me, it sounds like you may be experiencing some muscle strain or spasms in your lower back. I’d like to perform a physical exam to get a better understanding of what’s going on, and then we can discuss some treatment options.
Yes Type: That sounds good to me. Thanks for your help!

Questions: Before we begin the exam, I just want to go over a few more details about your pain. On a scale from 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain imaginable, how would you rate your pain?
Yes Type: I would say it’s about a 7.

Questions: Okay, and how long have you been experiencing this pain?
Yes Type: It’s been about 4 or 5 days now.

Questions: I see. And have you noticed any swelling or redness in the area?
Yes Type: No, there hasn’t been any swelling or redness that I’ve noticed.

Questions: Alright, thank you. Can you also tell me a little bit about your daily activities? What kind of work do you do and how physically demanding is it?
Yes Type: I work in an office, so I’m sitting at a desk for most of the day. It’s not very physically demanding, but I do have to lift some heavy files and boxes from time to time.

Questions: I see. And do you participate in any sports or other physical activities outside of work?
Yes Type: Not really. I go for walks occasionally, but that’s about it.

Questions: Alright, thanks for letting me know. Now, I’d like to start the physical exam. Please stand up and let’s begin by checking your range of motion. Can you try to touch your toes for me?
Yes Type: Sure. (Patient attempts to touch toes but experiences pain and is unable to fully reach them)

Questions: Okay, thank you. Now, can you lay down on your back and lift your legs up one at a time, like you’re marching in place?
Yes Type: (Patient tries to lift legs but experiences pain)

Questions: Okay, thank you for trying. Based on what I’ve seen so far, it looks like you may be experiencing some muscle strain or spasms in your lower back. I’d like to perform a few more tests to confirm my diagnosis, and then we can discuss some treatment options.
Yes Type: Alright, sounds good.

Questions: Let’s start by checking your reflexes. I’m going to tap your knees with this reflex hammer, and I want you to tell me if you feel any discomfort.
Yes Type: (Patient feels no discomfort)

Questions: Okay, great. Now, I’d like to check your sensation by lightly touching different areas of your legs and feet with this cotton swab. Can you let me know if you feel any sharpness or dullness?
Yes Type: (Patient feels sensation in all areas)

Questions: Of course, happy to help. And don’t hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns.
Yes Type: That all sounds good to me. Thank you so much for your help!

Questions: Hey, Mark. Good to see you again. How have you been feeling?
Yes Type: Hey, doc. Not too good, actually. I've been having this pain in my lower back for a while now, and I have a history of substance abuse. I'm worried about taking pain medication, but the pain is really affecting my daily life. What do you suggest?

Questions: Okay, let's take a look. Can you tell me how the pain started?
Yes Type: Honestly, I'm not really sure. I've been feeling it for a while, but it's gotten worse over the past few weeks.

Questions: And where is the pain located?
Yes Type: It's in my lower back, right around my hips.

Questions: And can you describe the type of pain you're feeling?
Yes Type: It's a dull ache most of the time, but sometimes it gets sharp and stabbing.

Questions: Are there any particular activities that make the pain worse or better?
Yes Type: Sitting for too long definitely makes it worse, but walking and stretching help a little.

Questions: Okay. And how long does the pain usually last?
Yes Type: It's pretty much constant, but it gets worse at night.

Questions: Have you had any previous injuries or medical conditions that might be related?
Yes Type: Not really, no. Just some minor injuries from playing sports when I was younger.

Questions: Okay. And are you taking any medication currently?
Yes Type: No, I'm not.

Questions: Have you had any previous treatment for this pain?
Yes Type: No, I haven't.

Questions: Alright. Now, I need to ask you some red and yellow flag questions. Have you experienced any loss of bladder or bowel control?
Yes Type: No, nothing like that.

Questions: Any numbness or tingling in your legs?
Yes Type: No, not really.

Questions: Have you had any unexplained weight loss recently?
Yes Type: No, I don't think so.

Questions: Okay, good. Based on your symptoms, I think it might be a good idea to get an X-ray or MRI scan to get a better look at what's going on. Would you be willing to do that?
Yes Type: Yeah, I guess so.

Questions: Alright, we'll set that up for you. In the meantime, we can work on some stretches and exercises to help manage your pain. It's important to keep moving, but we'll also be careful not to aggravate the pain. How has the pain been affecting your quality of life?
Yes Type: It's been making it really hard to focus at work, and I've had to take some time off. I'm just really frustrated with the whole thing.

Questions: I understand. We'll work together to find a way to manage the pain and get you back to your normal activities as soon as possible. Okay, can you tell me where exactly the pain is located?
Yes Type: It's in my lower back, kind of right above my hips.

Questions: And can you describe the pain? Is it aching, sharp, or something else?
Yes Type: It's mostly an ache, but sometimes it can be a sharp pain too.

Questions: I see. Are there any activities that seem to make the pain worse or better?
Yes Type: Well, it usually feels worse when I'm sitting for a long time, but it feels a little better when I stand up and walk around.

Questions: Okay, that's helpful to know. How long has the pain been going on?
Yes Type: It's been on and off for a few months now.

Questions: Alright. Now I'm going to ask you a few red and yellow flag questions, just to make sure we're not missing anything serious. Have you had any issues with bladder or bowel control?
Yes Type: No, nothing like that.

Questions: Have you noticed any numbness or tingling in your legs?
Yes Type: Yeah, actually. My left leg feels a little numb sometimes.

Questions: Okay, and have you experienced any unexplained weight loss recently?
Yes Type: No, my weight has been pretty stable.

Questions: Great. Now, can you tell me a little bit about how the pain is affecting your quality of life? Specifically, are you having any difficulty at work?
Yes Type: Yeah, it's been tough. I work in construction, so I'm on my feet a lot and lifting heavy things. The pain is definitely affecting my ability to do my job.

Questions: Okay, that's definitely something we'll need to take into consideration when developing a treatment plan. Thanks for answering all of my questions, Mark. Based on what you've told me, I think we should do a few tests to get a better idea of what's going on. We might need to do an X-ray or an MRI scan to see if there's anything going on with your spine or your muscles. Does that sound okay to you?
Yes Type: Yeah, that sounds good. I just really want to figure out what's causing the pain so I can get back to work.

Questions: I understand, and we'll do our best to get to the bottom of it. In the meantime, we can also work on some exercises and stretches that might help alleviate the pain. I'll put together a plan that's tailored to your specific needs and goals. Sound good?
